name: Penelope
title: Greek - Penelope
role: Queen of Ithaca, Faithful Wife, Mistress of the House
summary: Penelope, wife of Odysseus and queen of Ithaca, is the archetype of marital fidelity in Western literature. For twenty years - ten of war, ten of wandering - she waited for her husband's return, fending off 108 suitors with cunning to match his own. Her famous stratagem of weaving and unweaving a shroud for Laertes bought her years of time. Her recognition scene with Odysseus, testing him with the secret of their marriage bed, is one of Homer's most moving passages.
description: Penelope, wise daughter of Icarius, waited twenty years for Odysseus to return from Troy. She held off 108 suitors through her famous trick of weaving by day and unraveling by night. Her cunning matches her husband's, and their reunion after testing each other's identity culminates Homer's Odyssey.

homeric_context.role_in_epic: The goal of Odysseus's return; matches him in cunning; guardian of the household
key_books: Book 1 - Introduces her situation with the suitors
Book 21 - Sets the contest of the bow
famous_stratagems: Weaving the shroud by day, unraveling by night for three years
Testing Odysseus with the secret of the marriage bed

the_shroud.description: Penelope told the suitors she would choose among them when she finished weaving a shroud for Odysseus's father Laertes
the_shroud.stratagem: She wove by day and unraveled by night for three years until a maid betrayed her
the_shroud.significance: Symbol of her cunning matching Odysseus's own

the_marriage_bed.description: Odysseus built their marriage bed around a living olive tree, a secret known only to them
the_marriage_bed.recognition: Penelope tested Odysseus by suggesting the bed be moved; his angry knowledge of its impossibility proved his identity
the_marriage_bed.significance: The rooted bed symbolizes their unshakeable marriage

feats: Held off 108 suitors for years through cunning
Wove and unwove the shroud of Laertes for three years
Set the contest of the bow that enabled Odysseus to slay the suitors
Successfully tested Odysseus's identity with the bed secret
companions: Eurycleia (faithful nurse who recognized Odysseus by his scar)
Her handmaidens (some loyal, some betrayed her)

husband: Odysseus - waited twenty years for his return
son: Telemachus - who came of age during his father's absence
father_in_law: Laertes - for whom she wove the shroud
enemies: The 108 suitors who consumed her household
The disloyal handmaidens who served the suitors
